Intro to exuber

Source: vignettes/exuber.Rmd
exuber.Rmd

For our analysis we are going to use the EuStockMarkets dataset, which contains the daily closing prices of four major European stock indices: Germany DAX (Ibis), Switzerland SMI, France CAC, and UK FTSE. The data are sampled in business time, i.e., weekends and holidays are omitted. In this particular exercise we want to focus on weekly observations. To do so we aggregate to a weekly frequency and reduce the number of observations from 1860 to 372.

stocks <- 
  EuStockMarkets %>% 
  aggregate(nfrequency = 52, mean)

Next we estimate the above series using the recursive Augmented Dickey-Fuller test with 1 lag.

est_stocks <-
  stocks %>% 
  radf(lag = 1)

The summary will print the t-stat and the critical values for 90, 95 and 99 significance level. The package provides simulated critical values, so we use them by not specifying the cv argument into the summary function.

summary(est_stocks)
#> 
#>  Recursive Unit Root
#>  ----------------------------------
#>  H0: Unit root
#>  H1: Explosive root
#>  ----------------------------------
#>  Critical values: Monte Carlo 
#>  Minimum window: 38 
#>  Iterations: 2000 
#>  Lag: 1 
#>  ----------------------------------
#>  DAX 
#>        tstat      90%       95%     99%
#> ADF    1.453  -0.4201  -0.06302  0.6705
#> SADF   4.951   1.1416   1.41804  1.9863
#> GSADF  5.183   1.9693   2.20543  2.7487
#> 
#>  SMI 
#>        tstat      90%       95%     99%
#> ADF    1.770  -0.4201  -0.06302  0.6705
#> SADF   4.284   1.1416   1.41804  1.9863
#> GSADF  4.493   1.9693   2.20543  2.7487
#> 
#>  CAC 
#>        tstat      90%       95%     99%
#> ADF    0.987  -0.4201  -0.06302  0.6705
#> SADF   2.909   1.1416   1.41804  1.9863
#> GSADF  2.966   1.9693   2.20543  2.7487
#> 
#>  FTSE 
#>         tstat      90%       95%     99%
#> ADF    0.1945  -0.4201  -0.06302  0.6705
#> SADF   2.5563   1.1416   1.41804  1.9863
#> GSADF  2.6689   1.9693   2.20543  2.7487

The autoplot.radf function returns a list of ggplot2, thus we need to grob the list into a single graph. Function ggarrange does this for us, while we can specify the arrangement of the graphs by supplying nrow and ncol arguments.

est_stocks %>% 
  autoplot() %>% 
  ggarrange(ncol = 2)

If we need to know the exact of the explosive periods we can do so with the function datestamp. Datestamp works in a similar fashion where the use has to specify the critical values, however we can still utilize the package’s critical values by leaving the cv-argument blank.

datestamp(est_stocks)
#> 
#> Datestamp: Individual
#>  -----------------------------------
#> DAX :
#>        Start        End Duration
#> 1 1993-08-12 1993-08-19        2
#> 2 1993-09-02 1993-09-09        2
#> 3 1993-10-07 1993-11-04        5
#> 4 1993-11-18 1993-11-25        2
#> 5 1993-12-02 1994-01-13        7
#> 6 1996-12-02 1996-12-16        3
#> 7 1996-12-30 1997-10-28       44
#> 8 1997-11-11 1997-11-18        2
#> 9 1997-11-25 1998-08-19       39
#> 
#> SMI :
#>         Start        End Duration
#> 1  1992-05-05 1992-05-19        3
#> 2  1993-06-24 1993-07-15        4
#> 3  1993-07-29 1993-09-02        6
#> 4  1993-09-30 1994-02-24       22
#> 5  1994-03-10 1994-03-17        2
#> 6  1995-10-21 1995-10-28        2
#> 7  1995-11-25 1996-01-13        8
#> 8  1996-03-09 1996-05-05        9
#> 9  1996-06-30 1996-07-14        3
#> 10 1997-01-27 1998-08-19       82
#> 
#> CAC :
#>        Start        End Duration
#> 1 1997-02-03 1997-03-17        7
#> 2 1997-03-31 1997-04-07        2
#> 3 1997-04-14 1997-04-21        2
#> 4 1997-05-05 1997-05-27        4
#> 5 1997-06-17 1997-08-26       11
#> 6 1997-09-09 1997-10-21        7
#> 7 1998-02-10 1998-08-19       28
#> 
#> FTSE :
#>        Start        End Duration
#> 1 1993-12-23 1993-12-30        2
#> 2 1994-01-20 1994-01-27        2
#> 3 1994-02-03 1994-02-10        2
#> 4 1995-09-16 1995-09-23        2
#> 5 1997-02-03 1997-03-24        8
#> 6 1997-04-28 1997-10-28       27
#> 7 1997-12-09 1997-12-23        3
#> 8 1998-01-06 1998-08-12       32

Or we can plot just the periods. Plotting datestamp object is particularly useful when we have a lot of series, and we are interested to identify explosive patterns.

est_stocks %>% 
  datestamp() %>% 
  autoplot()
